G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3 because this action involves residential rental property located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3 because this action involves residential rental property located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the incidents described herein occurred in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where the property is located.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees that tenants have the right to enjoy their homes free from substantial interference.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 853.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants' rights under the covenant of quiet enjoyment, holding that substantial interference caused by a landlord constitutes a breach.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 853.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the scope of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and reaffirms that a landlord’s negligent failure to address known conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises constitutes a breach. The court surveys its prior quiet-enjoyment cases (Simon, Cruz, Darmetko, Dorgan, Doe) and emphasizes that, consistently, liability arises where the landlord unreasonably fails to act regarding known problems whose natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts uphold tenants’ rights where there is substantial landlord-caused interference.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 853.relevant_excerpt: “In Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. … Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently upheld tenants' rights under the covenant of quiet enjoyment, holding that substantial interference caused by a landlord constitutes a breach.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that serious interference with tenants’ use of the premises, caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, can constitute a breach. The court reverses summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim and explains that if the landlord’s failure to act to remove drug dealers in common areas results in tenants’ substantial loss of use, that may be a breach. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts uphold tenants’ rights under the covenant when there is substantial landlord-caused interference.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action … then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment."

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 358 N.E.2d 817, 8.proposition: In *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 358 N.E.2d 817, 818 (Mass. App. Ct. 1976), the court held that a landlord could be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment if their actions or negligence substantially interfered with a tenant's use of the premises, even if the landlord did not intend to cause a disturbance.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 358 N.E.2d 817, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects an intent requirement and holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the condition. The landlords here were held liable for constructive eviction due to severe noise from a lounge they leased to others, despite the finding that they did not intend to create the conditions, aligning closely with the stated proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 358 N.E.2d 817, 8.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done…. Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”
